[quote="Binomial-theorem"]The geometric mean of any set of $m$ non-negative numbers is the $m$-th root of their product.

$\quad (\text{i})\quad$ For which positive integers $n$ is there a finite set $S_n$ of $n$ distinct positive integers such that the geometric mean of any subset of $S_n$ is an integer?
$\quad (\text{ii})\quad$ Is there an infinite set $S$ of distinct positive integers such that the geometric mean of any finite subset of $S$ is an integer?[/quote]

Find the maximum value of $f(C)$, where $C$ varies over all admissible configurations.[/quote]
